results.name: The general form of the recurrences are the a(j), b(j) and n(j) solutions of the 2-equation problem 7*n(j) + 1 = a(j)*a(j) and 9*n(j) + 1 = b(j)*b(j) with positive integer numbers.
comment: The sequence a(j) is A157456, the sequence n(j) is A159679, the sequence b(j) the sequence given here.
Numbers n such that 7*n^2 + 2 is a square. - _Colin Barker_, Mar 17 2014
link: Colin Barker, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..800

Andersen, K., Carbone, L. and Penta, D., Kac-Moody Fibonacci sequences, hyperbolic golden ratios, and real quadratic fields, Journal of Number Theory and Combinatorics, Vol 2, No. 3 pp 245-278, 2011. See Section 9.
Index entries for linear recurrences with constant coefficients, signature (16,-1).
formula: The b(j) recurrence (this sequence here) is b(1)=1; b(2)=17; b(t+2) = 16*b(t+1) - b(t).
maple: for a from 1 by 2 to 100000 do b:=sqrt((9*a*a-2)/7): if (trunc(b)=b) then
mathematica: Rest[CoefficientList[Series[x (1+x)/(1-16x+x^2),{x,0,30}],x]] (* or *) LinearRecurrence[{16,-1},{1,17},30] (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Dec 25 2011 *)
program: (Sage) [(lucas_number2(n,16,1)-lucas_number2(n-1,16,1))/14 for n in range(1, 20)] # _Zerinvary Lajos_, Nov 10 2009
(MAGMA) I:=[1, 17]; [n le 2 select I[n] else 16*Self(n-1) - Self(n-2): n in [1..30]]; // _G. C. Greubel_, Jun 03 2018
